var.name: v1
var.labl: how important in your life: work (Q1A)

qstn.preQTxt: WE START WITH SOME QUESTIONS ABOUT LIFE IN GENERAL, LEISURE TIME ACTIVITIES AND WORK.

qstn.ivuInstr: Show card 1
qstn.qstnLit: Please say, for each of the following, how important it is in your life.

var.notes:
status (EVS_UK2, 2008.06.02 18:41): Approved Major change
translation note (S.Stares, 2008.02.08 13:51): In the 1999 questionnaire the British show cards were labelled alphabetically, rather than numerically as in the master questionnaire. I think the difference in labelling was trivial, and it would be much easier if we use numbered show cards in the forthcoming wave.

translation note (S.Stares, 2008.02.08 14:02): This change is just correcting a mistake which was made in the 1999 GB questionnaire, where a qualifying phrase was added to the beginning of this question. var.notes:
status (EVS_UK2, 2008.06.02 18:49): Approved Major change
translation note (S.Stares, 2008.02.11 11:35): See Q1: just to harmonise with master questionnaire.

translation note (S.Stares, 2008.06.02 18:49):
status (EVS_UK2, 2008.06.02 18:49): Approved Slight change
translation note (S.Stares, 2008.02.11 11:41): Here I would recommend using the instruction from the master questionnaire, since DK and NA are now response options for each item rather than separate items, as in the GB 1999 questionnaire. It seems easier to do it in this standardised way, and I can`t imagine that it would adversely affect the GB trend data. But I don`t have strong feelings about this, and could be persuaded to keep the old GB format.

var.name: f25
var.labl: flag variable: do you belong to: none (Q5a)
var.notes:
Flag variable: Indicates inconsistencies for the variables v10-v25.
Inconsistent 1 If respondent mentiones at least one organisation and "none". if v25=1 and any of v10 to v24=1 then f25=1
Inconsistent 2 If respondent does not know for at least one organization whether s/he belongs to it and mentiones "none".
if v25=1 and none of v10 to v24=1 and any of v10 to v24=8 then f25=2
Inconsistent 3 If respondent does not know for at least one organization whether s/he belongs to it and does not mention "none".
if v25=2 and none of v10 to v24=1 and any of v10 to v24=8 then f25=3
Inconsistent 4 If respondent does not mention any organisation and does not mention "none". if v25=2 and all of v10 to v24=2 then f25=4
Inconsistent 5 If respondent mentions at least one organization and does not know whether s/he belongs to "none". if v25=8 and any of v10 to v24=1 then f25=5
Inconsistent 6 If respondent does not mention any organization and does not know whether s/he belongs to "none". if v25=8 and all of v10 to v24=2 then f25=6
Inconsistent 7 If respondent mentions at least one organization and does not answer whether s/he belongs to "none". if v25=9 and any of v10 to v24=1 then f25=7
Inconsistent 8 If respondent does not mention any organization and does not answer whether s/he belongs to "none". if v25=9 and all of v10 to v24=2 then f25=8

var.name: f43
var.labl: flag variable: do you work unpaid for: none (Q5b)
var.notes:
Flag variable: Indicates inconsistencies for the variables v28-v43.
Inconsistent 1 If respondent mentiones at least one organisation and "none". if v43=1 and any of v28 to v42=1 then f43=1
Inconsistent 2 If respondent does not know for at least one organization whether s/he works for it and mentiones "none". if v43=1 and none of v28 to v42=1 and any of v28 to v42=8 then f43=2
Inconsistent 3 If respondent does not know for at least one organization whether s/he works for it and does not mention "none". if v43=2 and none of v28 to v42=1 and any of v28 to v42=8 then f43=3
Inconsistent 4 If respondent does not mention any organisation and does not mention "none". if v43=2 and all of v28 to v42=2 then f43=4
Inconsistent 5 If respondent mentions at least one organization and does not know whether s/he works for "none". if v43=8 and any of v28 to v42=1 then f43=5
Inconsistent 6 If respondent does not mention any organization and does not know whether s/he works for "none". if v43=8 and all of v28 to v42=2 then f43=6
Inconsistent 7 If respondent mentions at least one organization and does not answer whether s/he works for "none". if v43=9 and any of v28 to v42=1 then f43=7
Inconsistent 8 If respondent does not mention any organization and does not answer whether s/he works for "none". if v43=9 and all of v28 to v42=2 then f43=8

var.name: v67
var.labl: why do people live in need-most important (Q12)

qstn.ivuInstr: SHOW CARD 12
qstn.qstnLit: Why are there people in this country who live in need? Here are four possible reasons. Which one reason do you consider to be most important?
qstn.ivuInstr: SINGLE CODE ONLY

catgry.txt: B because of laziness and lack of willpower
C because of injustice in our society
D it's an inevitable part of modern progress

var.notes:
status (EVS_UK2, 2008.02.11 12:28): Major change
translation note (S.Stares, 2008.02.11 12:28): I`d suggest making the instruction the same as in the master questionnaire. I think with the use of CAPI in the field it will not be necessary to stress to the interviewer that only one answer is allowed.
translation note (System, 2008.04.28 14:56): Item status was changed from SLIGHT to MAJOR change by ACTP
status (EVS_UK2, 2008.02.11 12:29): Major change

status (EVS_UK2, 2008.06.03 11:45): Forced Trend
translation note (S.Stares, 2008.02.11 12:35): Is this an error in the database? `most important` is the question in this case, isn`t it? NB also in the 1999 GB questionnaire, `none of these` didn`t have to be spontaneous, but I note it is in the master questionnaire for this wave. I think it`s probably best to harmonise it, i.e. include `(spontaneous)` in this response.
translation note (Lucie Waltzer, 2008.04.29 08:40): This isn’t an error in the database. Please use same text as in Master.
translation note (S.Stares, 2008.06.03 11:45): ok
status (EVS_UK2, 2008.02.11 12:30): Accept trend
translation note (S.Stares, 2008.02.11 12:30): NB in the GB questionnaire for 1999 the words `one` and `most` are underlined (stressed).

var.name: f86
var.labl: flag variable: important in a job: none of these (Q14)
var.notes:
Flag variable: Indicates inconsistencies for the variables v69-v86.
Inconsistent 1 If respondent mentiones at least one aspect and "none". if v86=1 and any of v69 to v85=1 then f86=1
Inconsistent 2 If respondent does not know for at least one aspect whether it is important and mentiones "none". if v86=1 and none of v69 to v85=1 and any of v69 to v85=8 then f86=2
Inconsistent 3 If respondent does not to know for at least one aspect whether it is important and does not mentione "none". if v86=2 and none of v69 to v85=1 and any of v69 to v85=8 then f86=3
Inconsistent 4 If respondent does not mention any aspect and does not mention "none". if v86=2 and all of v69 to v85=2 then f86=4
Inconsistent 5 If respondent mentions at least one aspect and does not know whether "none" is important. if v86=8 and any of v69 to v85=1 then f86=5
Inconsistent 6 If respondent does not mention any aspect and does not know whether "none" is important. if v86=8 and all of v69 to v85=2 then f86=6
Inconsistent 7 If respondent mentions at least one aspect and does not answer whether "none" is important. if v86=9 and any of v69 to v85=1 then f86=7
Inconsistent 8 If respondent does not mention any aspect and does not answer whether "none" is important. if v86=9 and all of v69 to v85=2 then f86=8

qstn.ivuInstr: SHOW CARD 22- READ OUT AND CODE ONE ANSWER ONLY
qstn.qstnLit: Here are two statements which people sometimes make when discussing good and evil. Which one comes closest to your own point of view?
A: There are absolutely clear guidelines about what is good and evil. These always apply to everyone, whatever the circumstances.
B: There are absolutely clear guidelines about what is good and evil. However, deviating from these guidelines is sometimes justified by special circumstances.
C: There can never be absolutely clear guidelines about what is good and evil. What is good and evil depends entirely upon the circumstances at the time.

status (EVS_UK2, 2008.03.26 15:29): Major change
translation note (S.Stares, 2008.03.16 13:31): This is quite a large change from the GB questionnaire of 1999, in which a long list of denominations was used, most of them being small groups with only very few members, and with some categories which cross-cut each other (e.g. `Orthodox`, which could be Jewish or Christian; `Evangelical`, which could apply to several denominations). In GB the difficulty with classifications is the large number of small Christian denominations, some of which are very close to the mainstream established churches, and some of which are very different. I think the most efficient way to deal with this in UK is to use the `other - please specify` option, and to code the denominations afterwards, on the basis of the responses given. I would be happy to do this myself. The only thing I am nervous of is that it relies very heavily on the interviewers recording this question accurately, for probably more than just a few respondents. If the MG has a comment or recommendation here I would be very grateful for some advice.
translation note (S.Stares, 2008.03.26 15:29): revised GB categories - apologies - the note below refers to the next category (`other`)

var.name: f181
var.labl: flag variable: learn children at home: none (Q52)
var.notes:
Flag variable: Indicates inconsistencies for the variables v170-v180.
Inconsistent 1 If respondent mentiones at least one quality and "none". if v181=1 and any of v170 to v180=1 then f181=1
Inconsistent 2 If respondent does not know for at least one quality whether it is important and mentiones "none". if v181=1 and none of v170 to v180=1 and any of v170 to v180=8 then f181=2
Inconsistent 3 If respondent does not know for at least one quality whether it is important and does not mention "none". if v181=2 and none of v170 to v180=1 and any of v170 to v180=8 then f181=3
Inconsistent 4 If respondent does not mention any quality and does not mention "none". if v181=2 and all of v170 to v180=2 then f181=4
Inconsistent 5 If respondent mentions at least one quality and does not know whether "none" is important. if v181=8 and any of v170 to v180=1 then f181=5
Inconsistent 6 If respondent does not mention any quality and does not know whether "none" is important. if v181=8 and all of v170 to v180=2 then f181=6
Inconsistent 7 If respondent mentions at least one quality and does not answer whether "none" is important. if v181=9 and any of v170 to v180=1 then f181=7
Inconsistent 8 If respondent does not mention any quality and does not answer whether "none" is important. if v181=9 and all of v170 to v180=2 then f181=8

var.name: v192
var.labl: more important: freedom or equality (Q56)

qstn.ivuInstr: SHOW CARD 56 - READ OUT AND CODE ONE ANSWER ONLY
qstn.qstnLit: Which of these two statements comes closest to your own opinion?

A: I find that both freedom and equality are important. But if I were to choose one or the other, I would consider personal freedom more important, that is, everyone can live in freedom and develop without hindrance

B: Certainly both freedom and equality are important. But if I were to choose one or the other, I would consider equality more important, that is, that nobody is underprivileged and that social class differences are not so strong

var.name: v200
var.labl: opinion on society (Q59)

qstn.ivuInstr: SHOW CARD 59 - READ OUT AND CODE ONE ANSWER ONLY
qstn.qstnLit: On this card are three basic kinds of attitudes about the society we live in. Please choose the one which best describes your own opinion.

catgry.txt: A The entire way our society is organised must be radically changed by revolutionary action
B Our society must be gradually changed by reforms
C Our present society must be boldly defended against all changes

var.notes:
status (EVS_UK2, 2008.02.11 18:02): Major change
translation note (S.Stares, 2008.02.11 18:02): To harmonise with master questionnaire.
translation note (System, 2008.04.28 14:56): Item status was changed from SLIGHT to MAJOR change by ACTP
status (EVS_UK2, 2008.06.02 12:17): Approved Major change
translation note (S.Stares, 2008.02.20 14:59): Just changed `vis à vis` to something more straightforward.
translation note (System, 2008.04.28 14:56): Item status was changed from SLIGHT to MAJOR change by ACTP
translation note (Lucie Waltzer, 2008.04.29 08:54): Please use same text as master
translation note (S.Stares, 2008.06.02 12:17): I am really not confident that `vis à vis` is a phrase which is universally understood in the UK; however, I am sure that everyone knows what `about` means. I`m also sure that most survey companies would recommend using the most simple form of English possible in a survey. If you really dislike `about`, could I use `with regard to` instead?

var.name: v317
var.labl: did you live with a partner before (Q101)

qstn.ivuInstr: IF DIVORCED, SEPARATED, OR WIDOWED (RESPONSE TO Q97 IS CODED 3, 4 OR 5) GO TO Q105
IF MARRIED OR IN A REGISTERED CIVIL PARTNERSHIP (RESPONSE TO Q97 IS CODED 1 OR 2) ASK:
qstn.qstnLit: Before your current relationship, were you married or did you live with a partner?
qstn.ivuInstr: FOR THOSE NEVER MARRIED OR NEVER IN A REGISTERED CIVIL PARTNERSHIP (RESPONSE TO Q97 IS 6) ASK:
qstn.qstnLit: Did you live with a partner before?

var.notes: translation note (S.Stares, 2008.04.08 17:04): `civil partnership` is the term used in the UK to refer to a legally registered partnership that is not marriage. If by `registered` you intend a broader meaning, then I should change this. Please advise!

translation note (S.Stares, 2008.06.02 12:58): In the UK, higher education` specifically means university; `further education` includes pre-university qualifications and vocational qualifications. In order to capture all education, we need to include both terms.

E One or more of the following: NVQ Level 2, GNVQ Intermediate Level, BTEC or SCOTVEC First or General Diploma, RSA Diploma, City and Guilds Part 2
F One or more of the following: One or more CSEs below Grade 1, One or more GCSEs below Grade C
G One or more of the following: One or more O Levels, One or more GCSEs Grades A-C or equivalent
H One or more of the following: One or more A Levels or AS Levels, One or more SCE Higher Grade,Scottish Certificate of Sixth Year Studies
I One or more of the following: NVQ Level 3, GNVQ or GSVQ Advanced Level
K One or more of the following: NVQ Level 4, HNC or HND, Diploma in Higher Education, Teaching qualification, e.g. Teaching Certificate, PGCE, Nursing qualification, RSA Higher Diploma
M First degree, e.g. BA or BSc
N Higher degree, e.g. MA, MBA, MSc, MPhil

translation note (S.Stares, 2008.02.12 17:50): To harmonise with master questionnaire, with more natural sounding English.
translation note (Lucie Waltzer, 2008.04.29 09:05): Please use same text as master
translation note (S.Stares, 2008.06.02 13:07): In GB, `.` is ONLY used to represent a decimal point. So 500.000 = 500. We use only commas as separators. Also `and` does not make grammatical sense: the population of a town cannot be 500,000 AND more than 500,000. It is logically impossible.
Missing values from field questionnaire recoded into -1 to -5 values in IDS and NDS.
